1.1: 50 technicians to be trained through 1.2: One research conducted at a local university 2.1: 290 refrigeration technicians, customs officials, and coast guards to be trained 2.2: HCFC Phase out Management Plan/ approved Quota implemented 2.3: 35 members of Standing Committees (Parliamentarians) to be engaged through federal level workshop 2.4: 1 Workshop with Plant Protection department 3.1: 3 on-site independent inspections of for 1 targeted pharmaceutical and certification as CFC free MDI’s

1.1: Collaboration between National Vocational and Technical Training Commission and National Ozone Unit, Ministry of Climate Change on Training of the Refrigeration and Air Conditioning Technicians under “Prime Minister’s Youth Skill Development Program-2016 established. However, training programme got delayed. 1.2: Four Research Proposals from University of Karachi, International Islamic University, Islamabad, Quaid-e-Azam University, Islamabad and Collage of Earth and Env. Science, Punjab University Lahore received and reviewed. The committee recommended research proposal namely; “Spatial-temporal modeling of stratosphere ozone over Pakistan and studying its relation with climate datasets” as submitted by Professor Dr. Sajid Rashid Ahmad, Principal, College of Earth and Environmental Sciences, Punjab University, Lahore. 2.1: Over a hundred technicians, police officers, customs officials and coast guards trained. 2.2: Country Report/Article 7 Data report was prepared and submitted to the secretariat of Montreal Protocol and quota implemented

1.1: 01 seminar will be held 2.1: Data Collected from FBR/PRAL for HCFCs import on monthly basis, scrutinized and information reported 2.2.HCFC import quota distributed in accordance with 10% reduction target from baseline of 247.4 ODP tons.

1.1: 01 seminar held on ozone day 2.1: Prepared and submitted Country Programme Report / Article 7 Data report to the Ozone Secretariat / Multilateral Fund Secretariat (MLFS). This report is very important and is mandatory for all member countries to be submit in the month of May of every year. By submitting this report Pakistan stands compliance with regards to ODS data reporting. 2.2: Quota is issued to the selected importers under a set criteria. However, there is always a possibility that these few importers may able to format a cartel and stock the HCFCs in the peak season. This will result in price hike of home appliances which will have a direct impact on the end users / consumers

1.1: Extent to which target communities/village council engaged in supporting implementation and oversight of project activities [Scale: 1= Not at all (0%); 2= To a very partial extent (upto 20%); 3= To some extent (21-50%); 4= To a significant extent (51-85%); 5= To full extent (100%)]
2.1: Number of people including men, women and persons with disabilities benefiting from completed social services infrastructures 2.2: Evidences of improved access of communities to basic social services including market, education, health and livelihoods facilities due to restored community infrastructure [Scale: 1= Little evidence; 2= Moderate Evidence; 3= Consistent evidence]

comment.narrative:
1.1: 1= Not at all (0%)
2.1: 0 2.2: 1= Little evidence

1.1: To a significant extent (51-85%) (Scale value = 4) [Description: Target communities are trained to oversight the infrastructure rehabilitation work, target communities are resolving conflicts arising against project implementation]
2.1: 263,596 inhabitants including above 29 year age (Male 36250, Female 36802), Youth 18-29 (Male 26748, Female 24865) and Children under 18 Years (Boys 71065, Girls 67865) benefiting 2.2: (Moderate evidence, 60%) (Scale value = 2) [Description: target communities have success stories of improved access to basic social services including market, education, health and livelihoods facilities due to restored community infrastructure]

1.1- Extent to which target communities/project oversight committees engaged in supporting implementation and oversight of project activities All 92 project oversight committees were trained to oversight the infrastructure rehabilitation work. In addition the target communities have been on lead in resolving community conflicts regarding project activities 2.1. Number of people including men, women and persons with disabilities benefiting from completed social services infrastructures 185,646 individuals including 94638 men and 91008 women have been benefited with 122 community infrastructure schemes. 345 persons with disabilities are also included in this 2.2 Evidences of improved access of communities to basic social services including market, education, health and livelihoods facilities due to restored community infrastructure In 57 villages 122 community infrastructure schemes have been constructed/rehabilitated. Captured success stories reflects that project CBIs improved the access of local people towards basic services such as education, health, market and livelihood opportunities. Project has reached 185,646 people by restoring community infrastructure

1 Community/village councils are mobilized and trained for community development work in their area (Scale:4)
2 Target communities have increased access to social services including markets, education, health and have improved livelihoods due to improved infrastructure (Scale: 2)

1. Communities/village councils are mobilized and trained for community development in their areas. Target communities have been mobilized and effectively engaged during the implementation of project. Social mobilization team organized 50 project oversight committees (E01) which were trained by project engineers and social mobilization team in 12 sessions to technically oversee and monitor the civil work being carried out in their village under project. Community activists and member of village councils have given lead role in project supervision, monitoring, coordination with project staff and contractors and community conflict resolution regarding scheme, which enabled them to proactively engage in the community development in their areas. The project over achieved the target against he planed 48 community formations and 10 training sessions by formatting 50 POC and conducting 12 training sessions. 2. Target communities have increased access to basic social services including market, education, health and have improved livelihoods due to restored community infrastructure
Under this output community based infrastructure (link roads and irrigation channels), have been rehabilitated with the aim to enhance the access of vulnerable population to basic social facilities such as education, health and market. It also aimed to directly and indirectly contribute to the livelihoods improvement of local people. Total 48 CBIs have been rehabilitated against the targeted 48 (Eo2). This target is 100 % achieved.

1.1 8 companies visited the entire CBEs and negotiated products for sourcing, 1 invited members of 3 CBEs to Lahore for exposure and negotiated rates for Chilghoza pine nuts in bulk. Hunza organics signed the MoU with CBE Gais and purchased almost 30 tons of Walnut and 1 Ton of Pine Nuts from Hudur CBE.; 3 Companies visited European Trade Fairs and displayed products from the CBEs for onward marketing. 1.2 This is a process oriented activity, certification process is underway. The technical experts from FairWild and CBI visited the field again in July and October 2016. The documentation process was discussed and reviewed; training was imparted to CBEs, collectors and Business companies in both the provinces and the monitors. The FairWild auditor also visited one of the prominent areas for Chilghoza and assessed the potential. Most of the documentation is complete by now and the final assessment of the international auditors is awaited for certification or otherwise. 1.3 4 alliances have been established during the reporting period. 2 alliances are the communal alliances where CBEs of each conservancy grouped themselves into communal alliances. 8 business companies were introduced to CBEs, and were facilitated to the European markets with support of CBI for creating demand of the natural ingredients from the conservancies. On return, few companies like Hunza organics have made specific agreements with CBEs for sustainable sourcing form the CBEs. Officials of Dutch Organization PAKKA visited CBE Diamir and have collected the specimen/samples for scientific testing and marketing. 1.4 The existing legislation in Pakistan hardly provides any space for participatory management and business of NTFPs. The project reviewed the exiting legal framework in GB and KP and draft rules for extraction of NTFPs were developed in Gilgit Baltistan, which are currently under consultation with law department. While in Khyber Paktunkhwa, process of review has been also completed, where

description.narrative: Sustainable production of biodiversity goods and services through community ecosystembased enterprises
1 Increase in income for NTFP collectors and villages participating in sustainable NTFP production through CBEs

comment.narrative:
1 Currently NTFP is collected by nomadic grazers and poorer resident households Women and children are the main collectors Contribution of pine nuts and morels to average household income varies from site to site
Baseline values to be determined in Yr 1 for the following a household income from pine nuts and morels in target valleys
b Community perceptions of value of NTFP and expectations from CBEs in in target valleys

1 a NTFP collectors obtain 50 more income from sale of sustainably harvested pine nuts and morels to CBEs than from earlier sales to local traders and contractors
b Community members of least 810 CBEs satisfied with CBE performance and willing and able to continue CBE operations

The project is making regular progress in the direction set aside in the target It is too early to quote any percentage for part a however the community members are satisfied with the selection process initial meetings and tasks performed by CBEs The open collection of NTFPs in the valleys is banned by the CBEs for outsiders The value addition trainings have been imparted to collectors and a range of the NTFPs are collected and the information collected from the market on each species has been shared with CBEs This has encouraged the CBEs to initiate a case with the government not to contract out the collection of NTFPs from GB to any outside contract in lumpsum which is the routine practice of the government

description.narrative: 2 At least 20000 ha of critical habitat of target high value NTFPs protected for sustainable production of certified NTFPs in project conservancies

comment.narrative: 2 0 Ha of forest under certified NTFP production

2 At least 5000 ha of critical habitat of Chilghoza forest and 15000 ha of other high value target NTFPs in temperate forest in Astore Kalam and Dir Kohistan protected and under certified production of NTFPs

The areas for high value target NTFPs are identified in the conservancies meetings and discussions were held with communities to ensure conservation of the critical habitat through communal decisions A range of relevant organisations were contacted with the purpose to explore certification for selected species of medicinal an aromatic plants Finally FairWild due to its comprehensive certification standard for sustainable collection equitable distribution and health perspectives was elected The Action plan has been developed together with FairWild The future plans of the project include an agreement with FairWild visits by the experts to participate in the Business and Biodiversity Round Table BBRT and visits of the auditors to the field

description.narrative: 3 Landscape conservation approaches introduced resulting in improved conservation management of selected threatened species and habitats

comment.narrative:
3 Some conservation measures implemented by local communities but not for the following
a Leaves of Taxus wallichiana CITES Appendix I harvested ilegally for fodder and as NTFP
b Morel mushroom collection practices adversely impacts pheasant populations including globally threatened species eg White crested Kalij through breakage and collection of pheasant eggs

3 Improved conservation management of at least 1 significant threatened species or natural habitat type each CBE valley
a No illegal harvesting of Taxus wallichiana Himalayan yew Cites Appendix I in at least 610 CBE areas
b Collectors in 610 CBE areas collect morels later in season to minimize damage to wild pheasant eggs

Conservation measures agreed with 4 CBEs for imposing ban on illegal collection of all CITES Species including Taxus Walliciana
The morels are collected by CBEs according to the Terms and Conditions agreed with the project including late season right size and in selected pastures

description.narrative: 4 Strengthened institutional capacity for landscape conservation and CBE establishment and certified production of NTFPs in Pakistan

comment.narrative:
4 a Considerable capacity especially among NGOs eg RSPN Sarhad RSP AKRSP for social mobilization establishment of different types of village organizations including to a lesser extent enterprise development Some national capacity for organic certification of agricultural horticultural products Little capacity among NGOs or key government agencies dpeartments eg PFI KP GB Forestry Departments MINFAL for promoting biodiversity conservation through certified production of NTFP by local communities or for delivering extension services in an integrated rather than sectoral way
b No agency in Pakistan has experience or training to verify whether NTFP production complies with agreed certification standards

4 a At least 70 of CBE requests for additional capacity development support and extension services to be established in Year 3 are met satisfactorily by Year 4
b At least one national body trained and potentially accredited to verify NTFP produced under certification scheme

4 a The project is in its 2nd year of implementation
b Several national and provincial bodies including PARC NARC Pakistan Forest Institute NTFP department of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa have been identified for participation in the training program for possibilities of selection agreement to act as accreditation bodies under certification schemes

description.narrative: Market demand for biodiversity friendly nontimber forest products NTFP stimulated
1 Increased support for sustainable NTFP production use within private sector in Pakistan through Business and Biodiversity Round Table BBRT

comment.narrative: 1 No opportunity for private sector to preferentially buy sustainably produced wild NTFP as no certification systems in place
1 At least 3 major herbal industries in Pakistan include reference in their CSR policy to preferential buying of certified NTFP from project areas

The BBRT has membership from major industries and related institutions in the private sector Two meetings of the forum was held where most of the industries including Herb ion Hamdarad and Hunza Organics committed to purchase the certified products once available with CBEs as preferential buying of raw material as part of their CSR polices The industries showed interest in certification schemes and the process as well The market study was discussed in length and it was found that that the market study is an inbuilt component of the FairWild Certification package Work has been started on it

description.narrative: 2 Number of voluntary NTFP certification systems established

comment.narrative: 2 Voluntary certification schemes for sustainable production established for at least 2 NTFP including a Chilghoza pine nuts b Morel mushrooms

Work is in progress to explore the suitable certification schemes and the standard for at least for two species Morels and Pine nuts primarily in the European marketThe market study was discussed with the consultant hired for the certification schemes He has submitted his first deliverable and will continue work according to the TORS in the days to come

description.narrative: 3 Number of alliances with national international buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversityfriendly NTFP from project CBEs

comment.narrative: 3 At least 10 operational alliances with international and national buyers representing preferential markets for certified biodiversityfriendly NTFP from northern Pakistan

The concept of establishing conservancies alliance was shared with CBEs The work is under way to create a strong alliance of communities for extended market support to CBEs Communal alliances will be created by bringing CBEs together so that a consolidate approach towards accessing the market is obtained Formation of such two alliances are under way each in KP and GB Furthermore on the buyers side individuals and well collective meetings were organised with several companies for exploring the possibilities of forming national and international alliances

description.narrative: 4 Revised regulatory framework for NTFP collection trade

comment.narrative: 4 No comprehensive regulatory framework for NTFP collection trade A few special rules for some products
4 A comprehensive regulatory framework for NTPF collection trade that supports sustainable NTFP production

Currently there is no mechanism of sustainable harvest of MAPs species except a simple procedure of contracting an outside individual for unmonitored exploitation in the provinces The existing legislation pertaining to Medicinal and aromatic plants species was reviewed in Gilgit BaltistanGB and fresh rules were developed through a broader process of building stakeholder consensus The draft rules prepared are under broader review of the related institutions traders and community organisations in GB The rules will be finalised in the next few months

description.narrative: Positive biodiversity linkages strengthened at landscape level through CBE Conservation and Sustainable Resource Use SRU agreements
1 Number of specific biodiversity conservation measures successfully implemented by project CBEs at landscape level under their Conservation and SRU Agreements

comment.narrative: 1 Some biodiversity conservation measures are being implemented under Village and Valley Conservation Plans which will not be duplicated in this project
1 At least 2 specific and quantifiable priority conservation measures included in each of the 10 CBEs Conservation SRU Agreements and integrated into the relevant Landscape Conservation Plans LCPs

Developing Conservation Agreements is a long process Communities were sensitised for agreements Lengthy sessions were organised with CBEs and the relevant government institutions to agree on terms of partnership The project has reached agreement with CBEs on arresting illegal cutting of forests extending full cooperation to provincial forestry and environment departments decreasing poaching and putting a ban on illicit and unorganised extraction of MAP species in 6 conservancies These conservation measures are drafted in the conservation agreements which will be finalised and signed between the relevant government institutions and the authorised community bodies Conservancy Management CommitteesCBEs

description.narrative: 2 Number of collaborative forest management initiatives developed and implemented by State Forestry departments and local communities

comment.narrative: 2 Not applicable as there is no collaborative forest management in the country
2 At least one collaborative forest management developed and under implementation in every conservancy

Mechanism of collaborative forest management has been discussed and agreed with CBEs Joint consultations of the project Forest and Environment departments and CBES in the field is in progress at two demonstration sites each in Astore and Kalam Conservancies for developing Joint Forest management Plans with support from IUCN

description.narrative: 3 Number of communitybased assessments of CBE performance including economic and conservation benefits generated

comment.narrative: 3 Not applicable as CBEs do not exist yet However there is precedent of such assessments developed through MACP and continued through PMAC in relation to reviews of Valley Conservation Plans by concerned villagers

3 Annual participatory communitybased assessments of CBE performance used together with project monitoring and any other assessments to adapt individual CBE management including implementation of business plan and Conservation SRU Agreement

Regular monitoring of the CBEs performance is under way with support from UNDP the Ministry of Climate Change and the project itself Capacity building events on CBEs operationalisation and management including administration and financial mechanism were organised
The project also completed baseline for MAPs species in all conservancies with support from IUCN IUCN has been asked to initiate work on developing testing and refining biodiversity monitoring indicators for the project and establishing participatory monitoring systems to be used by communities for assessing resource status impact of interventions and recording changes for course correction

description.narrative: Strengthened capacity of local communities to produce and market biodiversityfriendly products
1 Number of conservancy villages valleys receiving support for CBE development management

comment.narrative: 1 Conservancy villages have experience of forming new village institutions and understanding of biodiversity conservation SRU principles a few have experience of enterprise development but none have experience of certified sustainable production of NTFP
1 At least 20 villages and 10 valleys receive training on the business and technical skills needed for successful CBE establishment participation in voluntary certification schemes

Eight CBEs were established and three of them were registered Necessary training on record keeping and CBEs management were imparted to help them shoulder the responsibility of running CBEs as business entities The training needs and assessment were completed in the entire project conservancies and training of best practices of collection post harvest processing grading packaging and labelling were imparted in all the conservancies Furthermore Training of Trainers TOT for the professional staff of Forest departments were completed as extension service providers to CBEs in future

description.narrative: 2 Number of operational CBEs with approved business plans participating in voluntary NTFP certification schemes

comment.narrative: 2 All Valleys have Valley Conservation Plans and Valley Conservation Funds Some have communitybased trophy hunting enterprises There is no communitybased certified NTFP production
2 At least 10 CBEs with approved business plans participating in one or more NTFP voluntary certification schemes
CBEs are sensitised through dedicated session for participation in relevant certification scheme for raw material of MAP species

description.narrative: 3 Community access to relevant technical financial and market information services for CBE development

comment.narrative: 3 No extension services currently available to communities for biodiversity business planning or sustainable commercially viable NTFP production
3 A mechanism for coordinated delivery of technical financial and market advisory services to CBEs in place and being used effectively by CBEs for business planning and development

Dedicated sessions of the CBEs were organised with the government financing mechanism as support to CBEs The formation of 4 CBEs and one national alliance is progress and will be completed by the end of June 2016 Such Alliances once in place will provide regular advice on market fluctuation demand and will link CBEs with the available institutions for technical and financial support to CBEs in the long run Grants were provided to 8 CBEs as incubator funds for operationalising CBEs Such grants will also be provided to the National Alliance for better coordination with the marketinstitutions and extended support to CBEs

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional capacity for scale up and replication of CBEs
1 Number of key institutions and agencies with capacity to provide coordinated support to mountain communities wishing to establish CBEs and participate in certified sustainable NTFP production

comment.narrative:
1a Targeted institutions and agencies have considerable capacity in their sectors focus areas but limited expertise in supporting biodiversityfriendly commercially competitive enterprises
1b No mechanisms exist for coordinated delivery of extension services
1c There is no partnership yet and hence no budgetary support for CBE scale up replication other than through the cofinanciers of this project MoEPMAC UNDP

1a Targeted capacity development of at least 8 major partner national organizationsgovernment agencies to support certified NTFP production by CBEs in northern Pakistan including KP and GB Forest Departments AKRSP Sarhad RSP IUCN PFI MINFAL
1b Mechanism for providing coordinated support to communities agreed and implemented by key partners willing to provide ongoing support to communities for CBE development and certified NTFP production
1c Committed budgetary support from the partnership of organizations to provide capacity development to communities for CBE scale up and replication

Orientation and sensitisation events were organised for the provincial and national government institutions rural support programs and relevant industries for extending support to CBEs Research institutions were engaged through establishing research stations for future support to CBEs Students are engaged in the specific surveys and scientific assessment of various parents of MAPs species in the field
The provincial government of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Gilgit Baltistan have generously agreed to provide their own moneys from July 2015 onward as cofinaincing from Annual Development Plans This will help strengthen the ownership of the government agencies and will also augment the project resources for extended support to CBEs and communities at large

description.narrative: 2 Number of dedicated follow up activities to systematically analyze document and disseminate project knowledge and lessons learned regionally nationally and globally

comment.narrative: 2 No project knowledge or lessons exist as the project has not started implementation

2a At least one synthesis report summarizing main project achievements and lessons in English and Urdu
2b Community to community learning facilitated by arranging for nonproject villages to visit successful CBEs
2c Project knowledge and lessons shared across northern Pakistan through PMAC the Valley and Conservancy Management Committees AKRSP Sarhad RSP and AJKRSP
2d At least one regional conference bringing together local communities government NGOs private sector and other key stakeholders to share project achievements
2e One national conference organized through the Business Biodiversity Round Table to share project knowledge lessons learned with key national stakeholders

IUCN has been engaged to support the project in these particular activities Thus a project website has been created and maintained through IUCN Data on the MAP species progress and various achievements of the project will be gradually uploaded on the website
Communal exchange visits national and regional conferences will be completed by June 2016

1.1 3 (Partially) Achieved During 2016, the Chief Technical Advisor, Mr. James Littleton conducted over fourteen official meetings with the senior management of Secretariat of Election Commission of Pakistan (ECP). These included six meetings with the Secretary ECP, two meetings with Additional Secretary ECP, another two meetings with Director General IT, and lastly four meetings with Additional Director General (ADG) – Gender and Training on a number of different topics such as GIS polling scheme, development of capacity building strategy for ECP officers, activation of gender and disability working group, ECP’s media strategy etc. Additionally, there were various informal and/or undocumented meetings of CTA with the senior management of the ECP to share best practices and international experience, in order to enhance ECP’s institutional capacity.
Moreover, the technical specialist as well as the Civic and Voter Education Officer conducted a series of meetings with Additional Secretary, ADG- Gender and Trainings, ADG Public Relations (PR) and other Directors to discuss and share experiences on key areas such as Development of trainings curriculums, training plans, media trainings, Interpersonal skills and capacity development training program for mid-career officers, leadership and management training for senior officers, activation of District Voter Education Committees, design and distribution of information education and communication material etc. Through sharing of international best practices, the new Members of the ECP as well as the senior management of ECP learnt about the complexities involved in the electoral cycle, and also about their enhanced role for upcoming General Elections 2018.
1.2: 4 (Largely) More than the target
During the Year 2016, the project organized BRIDGE (Building Resources in Democracy governance & Elections) Train-the-Facilitator workshop in Islamabad from 11-22 April 2016, in which 24 participants were trained (21 from ECP).
1.1: 3[Partially] 1.2: 3[Partially] 1.3: 3[Partially] 2.1: 3[Partially] 2.2: 3[Partially] 3.1 [100] 3.2: 2[Very partially]

1.1: 3 (Partially) In efforts to build the institutional capacity of the ECP, UNDP and the ECP jointly organized the four (4) batches of training on Electoral Management Course (EMC) and three modules of BRIDGE : Boundary Delimitation, Legal Framework and Gender and Elections for 113 ECP Officials (Female: 04, Males :109) with the assistance of International BRIDGE Facilitator. The core purpose of this course is to enhance the capacity of election officials on various aspects of election management in order to support long-term management and electoral administration sustainability of the ECP. By attending these courses, the insight of ECP-officials was enhanced on global best practices, combined with local procedures and practices.
UNDP also arranged a one-week training course on Leadership and Management for senior management of ECP (grades BPS 19 and above) at Lahore University of Management Sciences (LUMS) University, Lahore from 13th to 18th February, 2017. A total of 20 participants (F:01, M:19) participated in this course. The objective of this programme was to develop the understanding of officers on leadership and to strengthen their techniques for managing the performance of their team members.
UNDP has supported the ECP in drafting the “Women NICs’ and Voter Registration Campaign” strategy document. As a result of the support, ECP Women NICs and Voter Registration campaign has commenced in 79 districts across Pakistan as an effort to minimize gap between men and women voters in Pakistan. The campaign aims to register NICs of 800,000 women and reach out to 7,000,000 people for civic and voter education.
Assistance is also being provided to draft gender mainstreaming strategy for the ECP. UNDP is supporting a working group on ‘Gender and Disability Electoral Working Group’, led by the and includes relevant government and civil society organisations, to support the ECP by giving strategic support at the national and provincial levels in gender mainstre

1.1: Establishment of 5 STUs 1.2: Training of 3,930 trainees (operators, checkers, master trainers, merchandisers, production and quality executives, denim/garment washing workers and middle management) and 1.3: Training of 80 interns, where at least 75% are expected to be able to secure employment

Results 2016 1. Improved skills and livelihood conditions of target vulnerable youth of Karachi. There has been a significant positive impact of the project interventions on select vulnerable youth of Karachi. The project beneficiaries gained quality marketable skills in garment related trades and as a result, livelihood conditions of the project beneficiaries 2,452 youth (1,399 women, 1,053 men)have been improved. It further helped to decrease gender inequalities, armed conflict, violence, and extremism in the neighborhoods.
2. Increased capacities of local service providers particularly TEVT sector institutes. Through the project interventions skills training programs in garment related trades have been revived in the partner TEVT institutes. Project strengthened their capacities by introducing demand-driven courses and provision of technical resources. The project also played a key role in bridging the gap between demand and supply side and revamped institute-industry linkages. The project added value to the garment sector and enhanced its efficiency and productivity through the development of skilled workforce.
3. The project generated evidence based research papers through the experts/researchers and enhanced knowledge-base in the public domain toward labor intensive- garment sector. The evidence based research studies are source of indigenous knowledge for government to reform the policies and also informed decision-makers in the garment sector to adapt best practices. The project invested in generating empirical knowledge and identifying needs of at-risk young people; reshaped the model of skill development and livelihood opportunities.
Progress on Indicators: 1.1 signed MoUs with 4 large scale garment companies 1.2 Skills development of 1,048 youth (480 women and 568 men) 1.3 Recruited 43 young individuals as interns under YEP internship programme at partner TVET institutes

1. Recognizing the importance of engaging youth in productive economic activities, the Youth Employment Project improved skills and livelihood conditions of vulnerable youth. As of December 2017, the project trained 10,472 young men and women in demand-driven garment manufacturing skills to help them obtain employment in the garment industry. It successfully created employment opportunities for 7,265 of the trained youth from the marginalized areas of Karachi in leading apparel and home textile companies and home-based businesses. The data includes approx. 4000 new or better employment opportunities for the youth during year 2017.
2. The project successfully forged partnerships with 13 leading garment textile companies in Karachi. These partner garment companies invested nearly US$ 0.4 million on training the youth. The contributions covered training expenditure on transportation, utilities and other training costs to improve productivity and efficiency of the young workforce. Strong partnerships with the garment companies helped ascertain the supply/demand gaps, ensuring that training equips youth with skills in demand. It built the strength and performance of TVET institutes and helped them create linkages with the garment industry.

Moreover, the third training was conducted to foster the commission's ability to work with the media and to establish a media profile, 23 participants attended this training. The media trainings helped the commission to define its role by strengthening awareness for its mandate and functions. 1.1: Scale 4; Functional review of national and sub-national disaster management authorities was carried out in various forms. UNDP participated in consultative workshops on the National DM Framework and continuously assisted NDMA in implementing their national DM agenda, including monitoring the progress of NDMP in Pakistan. UNDP assisted NDMA in implementation of regional cooperation of the Heart of Asia Countries. PDMA KP was assisted in the development of needs assessment and early recovery strategy of the July 2015 floods and October 2015 Earthquake. A session on Private Partnership on DRR was conducted with PDMA KP; to initiate more investment on DRR in the province. DRM officials from 03 selected districts were provided trainings on community based DRM planning and were engaged them practically in CBDRM process in the districts of Tharparkar, Jaffarabad, and Chitral. 1.2 0 - No consultation held on Sendai framework. 2.1: 73; UC-level CBDRM implementation completed, which covers 73 communities in 3 selected districts (Chitral, Jaffarabad and Tharparkar). Community-level mitigation and adaptation plans were created Mitigation / adaptation measured identified and implemented in the 3 districts. 2.2: 09; To complete the cycle of CBDRM as specified in the proposed in the CBDRM learning report, 09 mitigation schemes were implemented in the three districts. The mitigation schemes consist of various measures which had been implemented after the consultation of community members and village disaster management committees. The mitigation schemes were flood protection walls, raised platform as well as check dam. 2.3: Though no target was planned at the beginning of the year. However , village level disaster management committees (DMCs) were also established in all 73 communities and were provided with basic training of first aid, search and rescue. Mainly male members are from youth group but with at least 30% female groups. 2.4: 0 ( no target planned ) 3.1: 1- P

No Target 3.2. No Target

1.1 UNDP achieved many planned targets at national, provincial and district levels and made significant headways in terms of initiating process of planned activities for upcoming year. At national level, UNDP is fulfilling its commitments for providing technical backstopping to NDMA for developing systems and mechanisms to address the needs for pre, during and post disasters. 1.2 UNDP continued its technical assistance to NDMA on formulating a national plan of action on Sendai Framework for Disaster Risk Reduction (SFDRR) to fulfil its international commitments and obligations of resilience discourse. 1.3 At provincial level, UNDP is promoting the importance of engaging private sector in resilience discourse as there is a clear mutual interest for the public and private sectors to work together. The private sector relies on the resilience of public infrastructure and services to conduct their businesses, and governments and communities depend on resilient business practices for a stable and sustainable economy. 1.4 UNDP worked closely with relief and rehabilitation wing of NDMA on consolidating early recovery guidelines. The process is in progress. UNDP closely worked with district disaster management institutions for achieving desired result planned for reporting period. PDMA Sindh and district governments of Kashmore and Ghotki were fully engaged during district level risk mapping and DRM planning process. During reporting period, draft plans for both districts were developed through consultative process at district level and tehsil level. Then the drafts were shared with all concerned stakeholders for feedback. Both district governments expressed their keen interest in implementing these plans and asked UNDP support for implementation as well. 1.1: Launch of National Report on MPI Use of Multi-dimensional poverty for public policy
The Planning Commission in support with UNDP Pakistan and Oxford Policy and Human Development Initiative launched Pakistan’s first Multidimensional Poverty (MP) Report providing poverty estimates at national and sub-national levels; at provincial and district level. Planning Commission adopted MPI as a compliment tool to measure poverty. These estimates provide baseline for the MP indicator of SDG1 and are also useful in in poverty targeting and informing the government decisions related to allocation of resources across provinces from the National Finance Commission award and across districts from the Provincial Finance Commission awards. Development Advocate of Pakistan produced and launched quarterly.
2.1: 4 issues of Development Advocate Pakistan published
In 2016, four Development Advocate Pakistan publications on Preventing Violent Extremism, Inequality, Civil Service Reforms and Water were produced. These policy publications initiated discussions on violent extremism in Pakistan which poses a significant threat to peace and stability; on bringing growing inequality back into the public realm; on civil service reforms and its importance to achieve 2030 sustainable development agenda and on the issue of water security in Pakistan and lessons for future.
2.2: Preparation and Launch of National human development Report
UNDP’s work on National Human Development Report on Youth NHDR 2016 ignited a national level debate on determining the critical role youth can play in advancing sustainable human development in Pakistan. Meetings with parliamentarians, civil servants in planning and development departments and youth ministries, civil society, academia and media were organized to share the preliminary messages for the report and build anticipation for Report launch. UNDP developed Human Development Indexes and Youth Development Index for national and subnational level as

In Punjab, SDG localization plans for two districts have been formulated, the districts ha been selected based on the performance on MPI.
2.1: 4 issues of Development Advocate Pakistan published
In 2017, four Development Advocate Pakistan publications on Financing for Development, FATA Reforms, Rule of law and women empowerment are being produced. These policy publications initiated discussions on key development challenges faced by Pakistan.
2.2: Preparation and Launch of National human development Report
UNDP’s work on National Human Development Report on Youth NHDR 2016 ignited a national level debate on determining the critical role youth can play in advancing sustainable human development in Pakistan. UNDP developed Human Development Indexes and Youth Development Index for national and subnational level as part of National Human Development Report on Youth. These HDIs will be instrumental in providing evidence-based policy formulation and programmatic interventions essential for creating environment for innovation in the areas of youth, job creation, and sustainable development. An HDI portal has been developed to reflect HDI performace overtime.
2.3: Actively functional Communities of Practice/ Advisory Committee on Inclusive and Sustainable Development (national) and sustainable urbanization in KP
UNDP’s COP/ACs on 1) Inclusive and Sustainable Development (National); 2) Sustainable Urbanization (KP) serve as a platform for linking knowledge, expertise and policy analysis to inform UNDP Programming as well as national development plans and innovative interventions. comment.narrative: Speaker's conference a conventional forum that meets less than once a year on average and lacks structured cooperation. Council of Chairpersons lacks structured operation. No code of ethics/ conduct in place of MPs or staff Federal and Provincial assemblies lack in-house legislative drafting expertise. New committees recently formed, no experience of new MPs on committee work. NA and Senate lack specialized legislative research staff. New institutions report to Parliament as per 18th amendment but procedure is unclear. Most newly elected women MPs (member parliament) lack knowledge of existing caucuses and gender issues. Newly elected MPAs (member provincial assemblies) lacking understanding of parliamentary practice/ business and new committees have limited expertise for oversight of MDGs, gender equality and devolution process.

comment.narrative:
1.1: 0 [Desc: The initial POPs pesticides as included in the Stockholm Convention before 2009 are banned in Pakistan, through the Agricultural Pesticides Ordinance, 1971. New POPs like PFOs and brominate flame retardants are not regulated in Pakistan.A PCBs regulation is completely missing. Regulation on U-POPs emission is not compliant with the SC BAT/BEP.]
1.2: scale 1 [No national Technical POPs management Guidelines]. 1.3: scale 1 [Inadequate specialized skills, financial resources, equipment and working tools by respective institutions dealing with POPs; Lack of dedicated administrative structure.] 1.4: 0 [Desc: Chemical Profile for the country was completed in 2009 by the International Cooperation Wing of the former Ministry of Environment.. The chemical profile includes description of the chemical management in the country, including regulatory framework and management of hazardous waste, which will obviously need to be updated as a result of the activity of the project]
2.1: Scale 1 [Desc.: Inadequate awareness of importers and custom officers on imports requirements; Inadequate POPs inspectorate services Lack of control on the export of PCB content of end of life electrical equipment.]
3.1: Scale 1 [Desc.: Inadequate resources for dissemination of information on the viable POPs alternatives]
4.1: Scale 1 [Desc.: Lack of guidelines on risk minimization procedures for handling, transportation, storage and disposal of PCB contaminated equipment. Lack of adequate legal provision for monitoring of POPs release and their effects to human environment; There are no legal provisions focusing on PCBs management.]
5.1: Scale 1 [Desc.: Lack of awareness, both for the public at large, decision makers or farmers, on public awareness on health and environmental risks associated with POP pesticides.]
6.1: 0 %

Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) In 2016, project has partially contributed to enhancing the understanding of the Government and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs) on the drivers of violence and conflict amongst youth by facilitating knowledge and experience interchange amongst them through monthly CoP meetings [[E01]]. These network meetings have successfully focused on various issues, suggestions and challenges related to peace building for future programming and replication of best practices by the network members [[E02]].
1.2. Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) The research studies undertaken under YSCP have informed project expansion in D.I. Khan and inclusion of interactive theatre and exposure visit interventions as one of the research findings showed that interactive and creative learning reduce youth’s susceptibility to radicalization and violence [[E03]]. The project has established partnerships with corporate sector donors (Telenor) and international research institutes (PRIO). These partnerships have contributed in operationalizing community centres [[E10]] and developing the research capacities of students at the University of Peshawar (UoP) [[E11]].
1.3. Moderately The Virtual Platform for Peace and Development (VPPD) is recently operational [[E04]] and adequately coordinated with government agencies [[E05]] for them to express interest in its development and improvement [(E06:E07]] for future policy guidance.
2.1.Scale-3 (Partially 50-75%) In line with the project theory of change which establishes that provision of constructive alternatives and improvement in standards of living can help steer youth away from violence and conflict; The project has partially strengthened youth resilience through the provision of constructive alternatives based on skill development training, mentorship, and engagement in sports and recreational activities in selected UCs of D.I. In 2017, the meetings were more focused on Preventing Violence Extremism (PVE) and conducted with the relevant development actors to discuss in-depth issues, challenges and suggestions related to peace building for future programming.
1.2: Largely (75% and above) (Scale value = 4) The project has largely achieved the target of completing research studies in 2017. However, due to the sensitive nature of the research studies and new directives of Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MoFA), it was disseminated to selected partners and donors. In 2017, the project has more strategically engaged government, donors and civil society organizations to a high-level panel discussions on empowering youth for a peaceful, just and inclusive Pakistan. The recommendations of these panel discussions have disseminated to a wider range of stakeholders for information and policy formulation.
1.3: Mostly/fully (Scale value = 4) The Virtual Platform for Peace and Development (VPPD) is fully operational and handed over to the University of Peshawar to utilize this platform for exchange of knowledge between various stakeholders and for future policy guidance.
2.1: Largely (75% and above) (Scale value = 4) The project has created an environment for innovation in terms of strengthening youth’s resilience against involvement in violence and conflict by offering small grants to the youth of the target areas to implement innovative projects at the community level. 30% Draft performance contracts were prepared by eleven target Ministries/Divisions assigning pre-agreed targets against Key Performance Indicators (KPIs) that are to be determined at the start of the financial year, and signed between the respective Ministers (and/or Secretaries) and the Prime Minister. The performance contracts are aligned with the goals of Vision 2025, Rules of Business, PSDP and targets already agreed in the Green Book. A detailed summary including these draft contracts, quarterly performance reviews, as well as a KPI Tracking Unit housed in the Cabinet Division, has been submitted to the Prime Minister’s Office for approval. 25% Consultations have been held with key stakeholders within MoPDR and the PMDU to determine performance-tracking needs and propose viable dashboard solutions that can allow monitoring and review of progress against strategic planning and policy frameworks – principally the Vision 2025 – but also, the PSDP, Performance Contracts, and/or the SDGs. 70% Detailed presentations and demonstrations have been organized with the international team members of UNDP SIGOB, and technical assistance products developed, to help government stakeholders arrive at an informed decision. Further efforts are planned in this regard, including the possibility of a study tour for these stakeholders to assess the SIGOB system as it functions in other countries, as well as access to the SIGOB platform for a trial period to assess its viability. 75% A key initiative under this Output aims to put in place the Prime Minister’s Innovation Awards and establishing an Innovation Fund. The initiative seeks to identify, encourage, recognize, support and mainstream innovations that improve service delivery, across the public sector. The project has developed detailed design documents for both the Innovation Fund and the Innovation Awards program that are based on a comprehensive mapping and review of ongoing innovations at the federal, provincial and local

A comprehensive civil service reform package based on evidence and consensus among key stakeholders from federal and provinces have been developed and will be presented for the review and approval of the Prime Minister / Cabinet. The following four reforms have already been approved and instituted: • The course duration for Senior Management Course (SMC) was reduced to 16-weeks from 20-weeks and National Management Course (NMC) was reduced from 22-weeks to 18-weeks. • A revision of MP Scales was carried out and notified by the Government. • The MoPDR with technical assistance

The performance contracts are aligned with the goals of Vision 2025, Rules of Business, Public Sector Development Program (PSDP) and targets already agreed in the Green Book. 2. Consultations have been held with key stakeholders within MoPDR and the Prime Minister Delivery Unit (PMDU) to determine performance-tracking needs and propose viable dashboard solutions that can allow monitoring and review of progress against strategic planning and policy frameworks – principally the Vision 2025 – but also, the PSDP, Performance Contracts, and / or the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). 4. Summary / presentation was made on December 5, 2017 before the Prime Minister (PM) on Civil Service Reforms including Project Uraan, reports of Government Restructuring Committee, Summary of Redundant Organizations and Rules of Business etc. 5. Decision of the Federal Cabinet is awaited. 6. Under the Executive Leadership Management Course for Officials in BPS 17 to 22, all four batches have been trained. A total of 80 candidates participated in the training. 7. The project also served the MoPDR with a best practice web-portal, which has been approved by the Ministry.

1.1-1.5: UNDP technical support and advocacy, led the Planning Commission to launch SDGs in Pakistan declaring it as National Development Goals. UNDP established SDG support unit at Federal and Provincial level (in Punjab, and soon in other provinces and regions) under Mainstreaming Acceleration and Policy Support for SDG projects. These units will facilitate SDG localization in Pakistan, develop SDG frameworks at various levels, build partnerships including those with private sector, and establish various financing frameworks for SDGs. To support these units, federal and provincial governments are providing resources on cost sharing basis. Based on these efforts Minister Planning Commission has been declared as SDG champion.
CSOs engaged for inputs from grass root level on SDGs prioritization and preparation of awareness and advocacy material.
2.1-2.2: Support provided for capacity building of Federal Bureaus of Statistics. Dissemination workshop on MPI/SDGs.
3.1-3.3: Project development, scoping of activities particularly in relation to financing for SDGs, Mapping SDGs on Pakistan Development Strategy.
4.1: Study on Motivation of Public Servants in Pakistan, discussion on decentralized implementation challenges of the SDGs at SDC conference and development of for Institutional Performance Index

Communication & advocacy for SDGs undertaken to advocate on high level ownership and commitment. Advocacy & awareness material on SDGs developed and circulated. 1.4: Private Sector framework developed identifying opportunities for establishing, promoting and facilitating private sector engagement in successful implementation of the 2030 Agenda

3.3: Analysis of budget and annual development programme with regards to their alignment with SDGs.
4.1: Draft for SDGs plan for two pilot districts (Rajanpur and Bakhar) prepared. Draft Institutional Performance Index prepared and tested.

1. New management plans for CKNP and DNP drafted, biodiversity corridor established 2. Capacity of CKNP, DNP and responsible Government departments strengthened for effective park management 3. Online platform to document and share knowledge, lessons learned, experience and best practices in park management, established 4. Strategies for mitigating the impact of climate change on local communities and mountain ecosystems formulated 5. Livelihood options for local communities identified, capacity of communities to benefit from such options enhanced

comment.narrative: 1. Management of CKNP and DNP is based on outdated management principles 2. Low capacity of CKNP, DNP and responsible Government departments to undertake effective park management 3. Lack of comprehensive knowledge management within and between protected areas in Gilgit Baltistan 4. Climate change impact on local communities in mountainous regions of Gilgit Baltistan not fully assessed 5. Limited livelihoods opportunities for local communities due to their unsustainable use and lack of incentives
